PETITION.TITLE: Joint Foreign Defence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and Senators in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, believing

that the presence of nuclear armed warships makes a priority target of the ports being visited; and

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to his assertion last Friday that he did not know whether his Victorian Labor Senate ticket colleague, John Halfpenny, was responsible for the strikes and bans or the threats of strikes and bans now affecting 30 metal trades employers in Victoria. Does he know that two weeks ago Mr Halfpenny publicly urged metal workers to vote for industrial action if agreement to a second tier wage increase was not forthcoming by last Thursday? Does the Minister also know that by a huge majority-about 25:1-metal workers rejected that approach but Mr Halfpenny's influence was sufficient to carry some area meetings in Victoria, resulting in the strikes, bans and threats to which I have referred in other questions? I remind the Minister that on Friday he cited the return to work by strikers at Port Kembla as justification of his softly, softly approach to industrial relations. Is the Minister aware that the Port Kembla dispute cost the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Australia between $20m and $30m in direct losses and probably even more in terms of loss of customer confidence? Is the Minister confident that his action in taking what he described on Friday as certain steps in relation to these matters will bring to an early end the Halfpenny-inspired industrial guerrilla warfare in Victoria or is he prepared, as with the Port Kembla dispute, to let the strikes, bans and threats drag on indefinitely?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether my attitude to industrial relations is fairly characterised as `softly, softly' or not. All I know is that this Government's attitude to industrial relations has produced far better results than were ever achieved under the Fraser Government, in which Senator Chaney was a Minister. Industrial disputation in this country has more than halved since this Government came to power. It was not so long ago that even the present Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Howard, said that if the Liberals were elected to government there could be five years of industrial chaos but that they would solve the problem in that period. That would, of course, be at the expense of numerous industries throughout Australia, adding much more to the losses incurred than the $20m or $30m at Port Kembla. I said all I had to say about the Port Kembla stoppage last week. Hopefully, that is now resolved. From what I hear, I believe it is.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney asked me to comment again on matters which he asked me about last week concerning votes in the metal workers union and things like that. I am not familiar with all those details. I queried some of them last week and I will query some of them again, but the substance of them is probably correct. The point of the matter is whether we can, by proper persuasion and negotiation, resolve these issues as quickly as possible or whether we will decide the matter in some other way. The bottom line for Senator Chaney, as the new shadow spokesman on industrial relations, is what he would do about all these things. The implication is that Senator Chaney would have solved the Port Kembla dispute in a couple of days. I do not believe that for a moment. I believe that is the greatest bit of hocus pocus I have ever heard. One has only to look at the record of honourable senators opposite. We can look at what people were saying on the AM program this morning about the period of the Fraser Government. David Hale from Chicago made the comment that the Fraser Government was seen as a government which had great opportunities to do things for this country. It ignored those opportunities and it failed--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the opportunities you have missed since 1983?

—`Alley Oop' sings out: `What about the opportunities you've missed?'. Of course, every government has difficulties from time to time in terms of economic circumstances and so on. But reading Senator Messner's statements does not give me a great deal of comfort. All he has between himself and disaster is his native intelligence-and that does not endue anybody with a great sense of confidence, let alone the electorate.

ANSWER.PARA: I will continue, as I said I would last week, to try to influence the course of events in Victoria. Hopefully, that will produce a result as soon as possible. As I said last week, I am concerned about interruptions to industry brought about by industrial pressure. I will do what I can and the Government will do what it can to resolve those pressures. But let us not have the pretence that there is some magic wand in the hand of the Opposition which it would wave, as it did in the past, to produce good results. I do not think that for a moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note all the wind that the Minister has given me. I ask him quite simply: Does he agree with the actions of his Senate team colleague, Mr Halfpenny, in respect of those 30 employers who are being held to ransom by the union at Mr Halfpenny's insistance?

—I answered that question last week, simply by saying: If the due processes of a union such as the metal workers union are not being followed, by Mr Halfpenny or anybody else, in relation to industrial disruption, I deplore that fact.

—Can the Minister for Education inform the Senate of the full costs of higher education places in universities or colleges of advanced education? Would the Government consider charging Australian students the full costs of their higher education places?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The full tuition costs in universities and colleges of advanced education vary according to the course being undertaken. Average annual costs, including a capital component, range from about $5,800 for law and economics courses in the advanced education sector to $24,500 a year for veterinary science courses in universities. The annual cost of a science or engineering course would range from $11,500 to $15,000 a year; so it can be seen that, in the case of university and colleges, the cost of places is high and, in some cases, very high. Quite clearly, it is a cost that average or poor families could never be expected to bear individually and, for that reason, our Government would never consider demanding from an individual student the full cost of a university or college place.

ANSWER.PARA: To go down that track, the track down which the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, indicated on the John Laws show yesterday that he would travel, would ensure that students from poor backgrounds could never contemplate a university or college education and it would ensure also that even many students from average and middle income families could not contemplate such a huge outlay. Only students from very affluent families would be able to contemplate paying $15,000 or $24,000, or even $8,000, a year. We would not contemplate demanding such a payment from individual students, because of the equity reasons that I have just outlined, and nor would we contemplate a policy that would ensure that our thrust towards having a much better educated and more highly skilled work force would be undermined. Every industry leader and large employer in Australia is asking the Government to ensure that we have education policies that raise the standard of education and training at the school, the higher education and the technical levels. Of course we are doing that, but to embark upon a policy, as John Howard has promised he will do, which would lock most young people in Australia out of education institutions would directly contradict the whole theme of what industry leaders and large employers have been saying, as well as having the dreadful consequences in terms of equity with which we are concerned.

It is very clear that the Liberal Party of Australia has given some force to what it is saying. It was not a throwaway line yesterday from Mr Howard. Earlier, Peter Shack announced some sort of an intended policy which would maintain the present number of higher education places and somehow graft on the 390,000 or so public full cost places. It was not made clear as to how it was going to do that, and I do not think that even Mr Shack himself knew the answer. However, John Howard's remarks yesterday were interesting, because they were a contraction of, even a resiling from, what Peter Shack said previously. He said that the Liberal Party will maintain a certain number of free places-not the current number, which would be in the vicinity of 400,000-so even students who currently have a public place in an institution can expect that benefit to be taken away from them in the highly unlikely event of John Howard ever being in a position to implement these decisions.

It is quite clear, and I must say that in one sense I welcome the fact, that the Liberal Party has stated what we have known all along to be its policies that any school or mature age student who aspires to a university or college education will have to get several thousands of dollars which, in some cases, is an impossible task. Students currently in the system, who have embarked on these courses, are often under fairly serious economic strain and are being assisted by their families, or they have part time and casual jobs or, in some cases, receive some assistance from the Government by way of Austudy. Those students who are under very stringent financial constraints in maintaining and being able to complete their courses had better ask John Howard what this certain number of places will be and, of those who have a public place in an institution, who will lose such a place and what will be the criteria for deciding who will be able to continue to have a public place and who will have to pay up to $24,000 a year. I think it would be irresponsible in the extreme if the Opposition failed to answer this question.

Our Government will continue to do what it has done so effectively in its four years. We will provide growth in higher education and we will ensure that growth is spread regionally throughout the countryside and that it is not just concentrated in the big metropolitan areas. We will ensure that that growth is attuned to the needs of industry, for more people in computing, engineering, business studies and the like, and we will ensure that access to higher education is based on merit and the principles of equity.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance both in his own capacity and as the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister agree with Mr Gerry Gutman about the reason the Government turned down his recommendation for a gold tax? I quote from an article that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald last week under the heading `Post Election Gold Tax Makes Good Sense'. He said that they turned it down `because they were not the sort of things that could be introduced before an election'. Will the Government give a written undertaking, as the Opposition has done, that if returned to office it will not introduce a gold tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not place any value on a written or an oral undertaking from the Opposition; anyone who does would have to be wet behind the ears. Look at who is leading the Opposition. The Treasurer who presided over the 1977 election campaign appeared in full page advertisements holding a fistful of fivers. Honourable senators will remember that big hand held up with ten $5 notes clutched between every finger with the Treasurer saying: `Liberals give you tax cuts'. There was a big hand with $300 or $400 in $5 notes. Then what happened? The tax cuts came through on 1 February 1978 but they were whisked away again on 1 July 1978. They lasted for five months. But we saw fistfuls of dollars and it was said: `Liberals give you tax cuts'. And so they did-for five months. That is the sort of Treasurer that the last Liberal Government appointed and now that same fellow who was Treasurer then is the Leader of the Liberal Party. So, whether there is an undertaking in writing or whether it comes from the Leader's mouth, anyone who takes any notice of what the Opposition says is a mug.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen nothing that was said by Mr Gutman, but I do remember what Senator Durack said-and I am very glad that he asked me this question. I remember, I believe it was on 10 August 1984-I could check that fairly quickly if honourable senators wished-a report in which Senator Durack was quoted as having said: `Of course, there was no justification for the exemption of the income from gold mining from income tax.' I also recall an article that Senator Chaney wrote that did not go that far. It is ironic, to say the least, that Senator Durack, who has been reported-and has not contradicted that-as saying that there is no justification for an exemption from income tax for income derived from gold mining, has asked this question. Senator Durack says that there should be a tax, but apparently Mr Howard puts in writing that there will not be a tax. Frankly, in a contest between Senator Durack and Mr Howard, I would rather believe Senator Durack.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question of the Minister for Finance. Will the Government give a written undertaking that it will not introduce a gold tax if returned to office?

—The Government has made a decision on this issue and the Liberal Party speaks with a forked tongue on this as on so many other matters. Apparently John Howard, the fellow who held out a fistful of fivers and then whisked them away as soon as the election was over, is saying and putting in writing that there will not be a tax but it is still on record that Senator Durack says that there should be a tax.

—Has the Special Minister of State seen reports today that indicate that a Tasmanian Liberal Party senator is threatening to stand for the New Nationals in Tasmania? Does such a party actually exist in Tasmania and, if not, will the New Nationals have to register as a party in Tasmania to allow that senator to stand as a candidate for the party? Is it too late to register such a party.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports that attribute to Senator Michael Townley an intention in some circumstances of standing for the Joh for Canberra campaign or the New Nationals-whichever title may be ascribed to that political organisation. I understand that such a party does not exist at present in the sense of either having an operational base in Tasmania or being registered there. The only way that Senator Townley will be able to use a party affiliation, as opposed to standing as an Independent, in the coming election is by being endorsed by a political party that is already registered. Although the current National Party of Australia is not registered in Tasmania, it is registered nationally and in each of the mainland States. Senator Townley could be endorsed by the national registered office or any of the State registered offices of the current National Party and stand in Tasmania. Certainly, as I said, without the registration of the New Nationals or the Joh for Canberra party he would be left stranded. For the information of honourable senators-this will be of interest to other States also-I point out that to be eligible for registration a party must be either a parliamentary party or a political party that has a total national membership of at least 500. Applications for party registrations are made to the central office, a State head office, or the Darwin office of the Electoral Commission. The next part of my answer is important. Upon receipt of an application, the Commission publishes in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and major newspapers circulating in each State and Territory a public notice of application for party registration, and invites objections to be lodged within one month. So there is a month for objections to be considered.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commission may refuse to register a party if the name or abbreviation goes against certain criteria which are listed in the relevant Act. Objections may be made on various grounds, as honourable senators will be aware. However, the important point that I want to make is this: In the period between the issue and the return of the writ for an election all action concerning application for party registration is suspended, including the one month set aside for consideration of objections. Hence, parties must be registered before the issue of the writ. It is quite evident from that that it is far too late for the New Nationals, the Joh for Canberra campaign or any such titled political organisation backing Sir Joh independently of the current National Party to be registered in time to get on the ballot paper as such a political organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Is the Minister aware that there has been a five-fold increase in the backlog of cases before the Immigration Review Panel since June 1985? What steps is the Government taking to reduce the March 1987 backlog of 8,823 cases, accounting for an average processing time of 7.6 months per person? In any review of the immigration procedures will the Government remove the current discrimination in the points tests against those people from non-English speaking backgrounds who have relatives settled and well-established in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that as at 30 April 1987 the backlog of Immigration Review Panel cases was 9,725. This compares with 1,648 as at 30 June 1985. The average time taken to process the requests for review which were finalised in April 1978 was 7.6 months. On the basis that requests for review to the IRP would be received at an average of 1,000 per month from January 1987 to June 1988, the following steps were planned to reduce the backlog to 4,500 by June next year and also to reduce the processing time for requests for review to the IRP: First, an increase of 100 in staff that are processing requests from 1 July 1987; and secondly, the establishment of IRP panels in Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth, in addition to those in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra, and the appointment of additional IRP chairpersons and members. The Government has had under consideration possible changes to migration decision-making and review arrangements, including changes proposed by the Administrative Review Council in its report No. 25, which was tabled in August last year. Very extensive consultations have been undertaken with community and ethnic groups and law bodies about possible changes. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs invited interested groups to submit their views to him by around the middle of this year. I can assure the Senate that this process will continue after we have been re-elected.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the last part of Senator Vigor's question, the Government denies straight out that there is any discrimination in the points test. It applies only to applicants in the independent and concessional category, for which the pass mark is 70. Bearing upon the point that Senator Vigor made about people with relatives in Australia, 10 points are awarded for sponsorship by brother, sister or parent, five points for sponsorship by uncle or aunt and a further five points if the sponsor is an Australian citizen. So it will be appreciated against that background, with a total of 70 points being required, that the points that are applicable to relatives in Australia is a relatively marginal part of the total points figure. As such, we see no ground for the suggestion that Senator Vigor has been making.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister represen-ting the Treasurer. I refer to the Minister's answer last week to a question I asked regarding a policy document that was alleged to be leaked to the Melbourne Herald. In the Minister's answer he suggested that a broad-based consumption tax, of the kind needed by the Liberal Party if it is to have the slightest chance of balancing its books on its tax and expenditure promises, had been rejected by the Government because, amongst other things, it would have boosted the consumer price index by 6 1/2 per cent. I ask the Minister: Would this increase be a one-off increase, or would it have an ongoing effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember the question last week. I said, I think, these words: `No country in the world has ever had a one-off increase in the price level of that magnitude'. The magnitude in question was 6 1/2 per cent. If I can put the record straight, that was correct at the time of the National Taxation Summit in 1985, but it is no longer correct. New Zealand introduced a broadly based consumption tax later in 1985-or it may have been early 1986; I am not sure-which increased the consumer price index by about that amount. New Zealand brought in a VAT-type consumption tax at a rate of 10 per cent. The consequences of that were that New Zealand had an inflation rate in the December quarter of 9 per cent. The annual inflation rate for New Zealand is currently running in excess of 18 per cent compared with a rate of less than 11 per cent when the consumption tax was introduced. So the effect in New Zealand has been a huge and, until now, sustained increase in the rate of inflation.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Jones asked me whether such an increase in the price level caused by the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax, or indeed any consumption tax or wholesale sales tax which increased the retail price of goods, would have a one-off or an ongoing effect. The answer to that question essentially depends on whether the higher price levels are locked in to wages outcomes in particular or whether they are not. If a consumption tax were introduced under the sort of wages system, or lack of wages system I should say, which prevailed in Australia in 1981-82 when Mr Howard was Treasurer and the then Liberal Government decided to have a flirtation with collective bargaining and market-determined wages outcomes which led to a wages explosion it is almost certain that inflation would go up to 20 per cent and probably stay there or maybe even continue to accelerate. The experience in the main, however, has been that when a major increase in the price level occurs it gets built in, at least for a time, to the wages-prices spiral and maintains a rate of inflation very much higher than that which prevailed prior to the introduction of such a tax. As I indicated the other day, that was a major reason why the Government decided in 1985 not to proceed with such a tax.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the question I raised last Thursday with regard to the serious implications for Australia of the Bureau of Statistics survey fore- casting on average a 7 per cent drop in investment in manufacturing over 1987-88. I also now refer the Minister to an article by Ross Gittins in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald in which, after detailed analysis of the latest statistics, the writer concludes that, above all else, Australia needs strong growth in manufacturing investment. I quote Mr Gittins:

QUESTION.PARA: The bad news is that the survey of expected investment shows manufacturing as the sector where the outlook is worst.
He further says:
This takes all the gilt off the gingerbread, really, because it suggests that we won't be able to go on trading out of our difficulties for much longer.
I now ask the Minister: Is the gloomy outlook for manufacturing investment one of the reasons that the Australian Labor Party has suddenly dropped Mr Singleton's `The worst is over' campaign slogan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anything that Mr Singleton said on television in terms of a campaign slogan is not the Labor Party's campaign slogan. That will be announced in due course.
—The worst is yet to come.

—The question is: How bad is the worst? Senator Puplick has provoked me by that interjection. The worst, as has been pointed out by a number of foreign exchange commentators in the United States of America and a number of business commentators, would be the dreadful alternative of the election of a Howard-Bjelke-Petersen Government. That would be the worst possible outlook. This Government has made no secret in the last several years that the process of economic recovery and getting ourselves out of the conditions created by policies of past governments would be a medium to long haul. The difficulties in the course of that medium to long haul will be considerable. They will be well managed, however, when this Government is re-elected.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not read Mr Gittins's article to which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle referred but, if he is making the point that a lack of improvement in manufacturing investment-I think he was referring more to outlook, as I understand it from reported comments, rather than actual investment-in the future would be a considerable difficulty, I agree with that comment, and I think it is a matter of concern. However, if I might take a piecemeal view of the situation, I have investment figures for particular sectors of manufacturing industry placed before me on a fairly regular basis, and I must say that, in spite of the survey material, they are most encouraging. I refer to industries such as chemicals and plastics, motor vehicles, steel on a continuing basis and some areas of the metal trades. They are the ones that come to mind in respect of which I have seen recent reports which are very encouraging in terms of investment-actual committed investment and foreshadowed investment. To maintain the right environment in which that investment will continue to take place and improve is, I concede, very important.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that information, and I now ask: Would it be possible for him to make publicly known some of that information which he has had placed before him on a regular basis and which might help to dispel some of the concern that undoubtedly exists throughout the economy with regard to this sector?
—That will be no trouble at all; the honourable senator will hear about it.

—I address my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Given that the Industrial Relations Bill will not now be considered until the Budget session, what does the Government propose to do about the threat to the Queensland and national economy posed by the Bjelke-Petersen Government's provocative, confrontationist and anti-worker industrial relations legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shortly the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, and I will be jointly announcing that the Commonwealth Government will initiate a High Court of Australia constitutional challenge to the Queensland Industrial (Commercial Practices) Act 1984-87. Proceedings will be commenced as soon as possible-that is expected to be within the next two or three weeks-seeking a declaration by the High Court that the Queensland Act is constitutionally invalid to the extent of its inconsistency with the relevant provisions of existing Commonwealth legislation, including the Trade Practices Act 1974 and the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's initiation of these proceedings follows last week's decision to withdraw the Industrial Relations Bill for a further round of consultations. When reintroduced after the election in the Budget session, that Bill will continue to contain explicit provisions overriding intrusive and inappropriate legislation by State governments, including the Queensland Government. The Commonwealth Government has taken the view that, because of the delay necessarily now involved in that legislative process, action is necessary in the interim to minimise the damage that may flow to the national economy from the unhindered operation of the Queensland legislation.

The Queensland Premier has made it all too plain that, for reasons of his own perceived political advantage, he is determined to use the Queensland Act to provoke major industrial confrontation at the first available opportunity and that he sees the export coal industry as his likely battleground. The Commonwealth Government wishes to make it equally plain that it will not tolerate the national economy being made hostage in this way. Coal is our top export earner. Last year it generated over $5 billion in export income-that is, around 16 per cent of our total income-and Queensland coal exports alone earned something over $3.2 billion.

In the present very dangerously oversupplied world market, with producers in a great many different countries fighting for available contracts, the loss of Queensland exports for any extended period would not only gravely undermine our balance of payments and national economic recovery in the short term but also put at risk the whole long term future of the Australian coal industry. It is considerations of this kind that lie behind the Government's decision which, as I have indicated, will be to initiate, at the earliest possible opportunity, the constitutional challenge to which I have referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Earlier in Question Time the Minister sought to distort the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia on tertiary education. The Liberal Party has a policy of allowing students who do not make the quota to enter tertiary institutions under the same conditions as are applicable to foreign students. Will the Minister explain what the Labor Government can offer to more than 20,000 young people a year-and that number is growing-who qualify but are unable to gain entry into a tertiary institution in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —To begin with, in order to refute the suggestion in Senator Parer's question that I distorted what John Howard, the present Leader of the Liberal Party, said yesterday, I quote from a transcript of his interview with John Laws when he said this--
—Be careful when you are quoting.
—The honourable senator owes me an apology but that is another matter. I will get on to that. John Laws asked:

ANSWER.PARA: What are you going to do about tertiary education fees?
If this quote is wrong I hope Senator Chaney will leap to his feet and contradict what I will now read out from the transcript of what his Leader said. Mr Howard said:

We have got a policy on that and that is simply that we will preserve a certain number of free places, via higher educational scholarships. Over and above that we will allow universities to take any number of additional students and charge them if they like, full fees for taking them in.

I think that statement is pretty clear. I think honourable senators will also think it is clear, unless Senator Chaney wants to say that a word was left out, that a `not' was left out or something of that nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Catholic Education Commission accused you of that.
—Be careful about that. An apology will be forthcoming from Senator Teague on that foul misrepresentation.
—I very much doubt it.
—I imagine that it would not be in order for me to point out that if Senator Teague would like to raise that matter with me again in Question Time today, he will get the shock of his life.
—Like Senator Boswell.

—Yes, the Boswell treatment. Senator Chaney wants to distract attention from the seriousness of what has been said by John Howard, that extra higher education for any new places will be paid for at full cost by the students; and that since there has been no commitment to maintaining the existing number of higher education places some students who presently have free places, may find next year that they have to pay $25,000, or $8,000 or $10,000 according to what fee they have. It also been suggested that public places will be allocated by what are called scholarships. Who will allocate them? We know that the Federal Opposition wants to get away from any central planning or policy making. Will States have the right to allocate as many as they want?
—They will be allocated on merit.

—John Howard did not say anything about that. Who will allocate them? Will Senator Teague allocate them? That would be interesting. The point is that John Howard has now said that university and college students will be paying full tuition costs, except for that few unnamed numbers who will have scholarships. That is the big news of the day with regard to higher education places. Senator Parer asks what our Government will do about unmet demand. Our Government has an outstanding record in meeting demands. It has about 40,000 extra students enrolled in higher education than when we took office. So the unmet demand, whatever it is, would be at least 40,000 worse if the Liberals had maintained their position in office. We have an extra 40,000 already enrolled; we have had a growth rate of places in the vicinity of 3 per cent amounting to a growth of over 14 per cent during our period in office. So students aspiring to education can be confident that we have a proven track record of increasing the number of places available. We will continue to do that and in the August Budget we will bring down triennial funding. We have volume one available to us which makes recommendations about meeting unmet demands.

ANSWER.PARA: What students, people aspiring to be students and other persons who are interested, such as industry leaders, employers and the like, will do is look at the Fraser Government's record where in a four-year period it created only 8,000 places. They will also look at our record of creating 40,000 extra enrolments in our four years in office. They will look at the Opposition's promise to introduce tuition fees, which will mean that the unmet demand will vanish overnight because people will no longer demand places if they cost them $25,000 a year. They will contrast that with our record of constant sustained growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. I have been very patient because in this excitable, pre-election atmosphere one can understand the Minister running away at the mouth. However, the Minister has been on her feet for a long time debating this question. She is now making further gross misrepresentations about Opposition policy positions. She is clearly abusing Question Time for partisan political interests. I submit that she should be called to order and told to sit down.
—Order! There is no point of order. There have been a number of lengthy questions and lengthy answers. I remind the Minister that her answer has been particularly long, but she is in order.
—Our Government has an outstanding record of creating growth in the higher education sector. The electorate can make up its mind about which track record it would prefer and have more confidence in.

—I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister explain what the Labor Government can offer to more than 20,000 young people who are currently qualified but unable to attend a tertiary institution? At least Liberal Party policy offers those people hope.

—Senator Parer talks about more than 20,000 young people. That is an exaggeration, but I will let that pass. I do not know why he thinks that the many thousands of young people who did not get a place of their choice this year have a burning desire to change that by paying $25,000-or even $12,000 or $8,000-a year. We offer them growth in the system next year. There is still capacity in tertiary institutions. The last time I checked with the Tertiary Education Commission about 10 institutions had places available, but these were places in courses which had not been chosen by the students. Obviously, many of those students prefer to wait and try again for the particular course they wish to follow. There will be growth next year. Others may reconsider their choices and opt to take a place that is currently available or will be available next year. Others may decide to take the higher school certificate, or whatever the qualification of the assessment system they are in, in order to get a higher place. There are choices, there is capacity in the education system and under our Government there will continue to be growth.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Defence been drawn to comments made by the Opposition spokesman on defence, the honourable member for McPherson, Mr Peter White, that a Liberal Government might renege on the submarine project? Will the Government proceed to enter contracts for the new submarine project? Do Mr White's comments show that he is unsuited for the Defence portfolio and that the Leader of the Opposition should replace him?
—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. That is a gross misstatement of fact. Mr White has never made a statement that the Liberal Party would renege on the contract.
—There is no point of order. I listened to the question: It seeks information and requests action from the Minister and therefore it is in order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to statements from Mr White, which received very wide circulation, to the effect that the Liberals might renege on the submarine project in the unlikely event that they win government on 11 July. I understand that Mr White said that a Liberal government would not necessarily honour the contract for the $4 billion project. I notice that since Mr White made these statements a large Monty Python foot has descended on his head from his Liberal colleagues, particularly those from South Australia who are appalled by his remarks. Mr White has not been heard from since on that or any other matter. By comparison, the Government is fully committed to proceeding with negotiations on the submarine contract. Those negotiations are nearly complete. Any delay now would severely set back the entire project, probably for years, with very serious consequences for the capacity of our defence forces. A further result of such action would be the loss of 600 jobs in South Australia, 800 in New South Wales and 500, on present estimates, in Victoria. In addition it would cause a significant crisis of confidence in Australian industry and the loss of a very valuable transfer of technology.

ANSWER.PARA: Faced with these realities, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has stated his own commitment to the submarine contract but he has not yet taken the obvious step of sacking his shadow Minister, Mr White, for his half-baked remarks in seeking to renege on a project which is obviously so vital to Australia's industry, employment and security. I suppose Mr Howard took the view that it was hardly worth the unequal struggle of sacking Mr White when he had those other crazed defence loons running around the country, such as Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and the Leader of the National Party, Mr Sinclair, advancing propositions that were just as half-baked. Bjelke-Petersen proposed to abandon submarines altogether and replace them with patrol boats, which indicates a sophistication in defence policy matters which even Senator MacGibbon would acknowledge to be somewhat lacking around the edges. We have also had Mr Sinclair reaffirming his belief that Australia should get a nuclear submarine and the nuclear infrastructure to support it, at the same time indicating that Adelaide was not the preferred site for the submarine project as far as he was concerned and, more generally, South Australia was unsuitable.

I conclude by saying that the Opposition's views on this subject, when looked at as a whole and taking account not only of what its spokesmen have said, but also what the other putative members of the future conservative coalition gaggle are saying, demonstrate what a chaotic rabble Opposition members are and how manifestly incompetent they are not only to govern the country as a whole but to manage and defend our security.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Education to claims that she has made about the number of student places created under this Government, specifically to her 19 January claim of 36,800, her 25 February claim of 40,000 and her 5 March claim of 48,000. Is it not a fact that Estimates committee figures reveal the true figure to be 32,900-that is approximately 15,000 students less than her claim of 5 March? Is it not a fact that the Minister has been inflating her figures deliberately by including the student places created in 1983 as a result of the Fraser Liberal Government's policies, particularly the policies pursued in the 1982-83 Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman clearly does not understand the method of assessing the number of enrolments in higher education institutions. I suppose that I had better take up a bit of the time of the Senate to explain it to her. Firstly, there is a difference between equivalent full time places and numbers of enrolments. The number of places is lower than the number of enrolments because some places are occupied by more than one student; that is, part time students who do one or two subjects do not take up a full place. Therefore, given that we have a fairly significant part time enrolment in most of our institutions there will always be--
—Not any more. The $250 fees put paid to them.

—It is very difficult when Senator Newman persists with this ignorance. If she would like to have a briefing from officers of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission or read CTEC annual reports, or something of that nature, it would really help her to ask questions that have some point and meaning. The fact is that firstly I am trying to explain to Senator Newman that the number of places always will be lower than the number of enrolments because some of those places are filled by part time students-some do a half time load, some do a single unit study and so forth. There will be several thousand more students enrolled than there are equivalent full time places. That explains the first difficulty that Senator Newman has been labouring under.

ANSWER.PARA: The second, of course, is that the final census on current enrolments is not yet complete. CTEC has yet to get final enrolment figures from all institutions. Senator Newman would know if she interested herself in these matters that enrolments in some institutions are accepted very late and that students may withdraw at this stage of the year and so on. So the number that would have been available, for example, at the time of Estimates committees would not now be the current number. The current number would be higher-it would certainly be different-because late enrolments would have been accepted, there would have been changes from part time to full time or full time to part time and so on. So the figure is a shifting figure but the current figure is in the vicinity of 40,000 enrolments.

It is also the case that some institutions are not entirely accurate in the assessment of their student numbers and put in a later correction. In fact, our funding mechanisms take into account the possibility of variation because we compensate institutions that may have had larger enrolments than they advised us of at the beginning of the year. So there is a shifting figure of the number of students in higher education. I hope that explanation has assisted Senator Newman. What is entirely clear is that in the vicinity of 36,000 new places have been created and in the vicinity of 40,000 extra enrolments. But Senator Newman is very welcome to check the current figures from CTEC, which may vary a little bit. In conclusion, overwhelmingly there has been substantial growth, both in places and in enrolments, under our Government which will demonstrate our commitment to this very important area of government activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister tell us what reliance we can place on her own Press statements of January, February and March and the figures with which she then tried to mislead the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how long the Senate wants to be delayed while Senator Newman's deliberate misunderstandings take up the time of the Senate. The reply given in Senate Estimates Committee D to Senator Teague, who questioned the variation between figures, was:

ANSWER.PARA: The 1986-87 budget estimated that an extra 36,800 equivalent full-time student places will have been created between 1983 and 1987.
This is the figure in the press release of 19 January 1987 and is consistent with the information in the 1986-87 Budget Paper No. 1, page 98.
The figure of 48,000 in the press release of 5 March 1987 refers to the increase in higher education enrolments between 1982 the last full year of the Fraser Government and 1986.

The figure of 40,000 referred to in the press release of 25 February 1987 refers to the increase in higher education student enrolments between 1983 and 1986. The source was CTEC's Selected Statistics for Universities and CAEs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Special Minister of State been drawn to a claim in today's Brisbane Telegraph, made by the Premier of Queensland, that the Hawke Government, when re-elected, would change the Federal electoral boundaries to entrench itself in office? Has the Premier of Queensland become so muddled in his thinking that he believes that what he can do to electoral boundaries in Queensland can also be done at the Federal level? Is it a fact that the Federal Parliament cannot veto Australian Electoral Commission decisions and cannot direct the Commission in any way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports in today's Brisbane Telegraph to the effect that the Premier of Queensland said that if the Hawke Government won another term it would change the electoral boundaries to entrench itself in office and make it extremely difficult for Opposition parties to gain financial support. They are clearly quite outrageous misrepresentations of the situation obtaining under Federal legislation. The fact is that no Australian government can entrench itself by manipulation of the boundaries.
—It is only the Constitution that protects it, not Federal legislation.

—Does Senator Durack dispute this? The fact is that, whereas it is quite clear that the Queensland Government has a system of gerrymandered electorates in order to ensure its continued existence against the will of the people, it is not the case at the Federal level. It must be said that when electors in Australia go to the polls on 11 July they will be voting under one of the fairest electoral systems devised. It is a tribute to this Parliament, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and, indeed, the Australian Electoral Commission that that is the case. Australians who go to the polls can do so with utter confidence that there has been no rigging of electoral boundaries in order to sustain one particular political party in power rather than another.

ANSWER.PARA: When Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen says that the Hawke Government would make it extremely difficult for Opposition parties to gain financial support that is again a slight misrepresentation in that, of course, it is the will of the Parliament that some hurdles be placed in the way of political organisations, parties and candidates seeking political support by way of raising donations. It is not surprising that Sir Joh should be worried about the fact that we do set certain hurdles-mainly to do with disclosure-in the way of those who would support political parties and candidates by way of donation. Already in this chamber the remarks attributed to Sir Robert Sparkes in early March have been looked at from the point of view of demonstrating the utter contempt which the Queensland Nationals have for our democratic electoral processes. He was quoted as saying:
If they ever came into power in this parliament they would retrospectively alter the law to ensure that there was no disclosure of those who made donations to political parties.

Of course, it is very important and very necessary for Australians to know who those faceless millionaires are who allegedly stand behind Sir Joh's campaign ready to cough up the $25m which he mentioned in Los Angeles as being a very necessary sum for him to build his campaign on, so that we may know who may be purchasing the political influence that can go with anonymous donations. It is the decision of this Parliament that the veil of anonymity be stripped from those who would make those sorts of donations. Insofar as it is the will of this Parliament, I am quite sure that it is also well supported in the Australian electorate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. It follows Senator Elstob's pathetic and misleading attempt to play South Australian politics about the submarine project.

—Mr President, I take a point or order. My question was not pathetic. It is about time that Senator Chaney started speaking the truth. I did not ask a pathetic question and I ask him to withdraw that remark.
—There is no point of order, Senator Elstob, but I think you have made your point.

—My question follows Senator Elstob's pathetic and misleading attempt to play South Australian politics about the submarine project. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that both of the final contenders chose South Australia as the contract site, so that there is no question of the project being lost to South Australia? I further ask the Minister whether it is a fact that the Chairman of the Caucus sub-committee on defence manufacturing, Mr Allan Morris, a Labor member from a New South Wales seat, was so concerned by what he found in relation to the evaluation process that he prepared a lengthy submission for Cabinet and he suggested:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Navy be required to reconsider their evaluation process and recommendations and that prior to finalisation of tenders the following occur:
(a) Determination of the motor to be used.
(b) Determination of the question of the range of the German vessel.
(c) Absolute clarification of the noise level of the German vessel.
(d) Detailed interpretation of `fixed price' and `performance guarantees', by a department other than Defence, and their likely impact on the cost of the project.

In light of these matters raised by the Caucus sub-committee on defence, what consideration has the Government given to these matters and to what extent has it affected the Government's preparedness to enter into the contracts with respect to the submarines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first part of Senator Chaney's question, it is my understanding that Adelaide was the preferred choice of both contenders. That fact makes the reaction of the honourable member for McPherson more absurd and the right honour- able member for New England from the Opposition side even more extraordinary. They suggested that it was inappropriate that Adelaide be chosen, or that there were some remaining questions to be answered in relation to the choice of the site. I am sure that honourable senators opposite from South Australia would regard that suggestion as offensive; it is certainly one that Senator Elstob and others, including Mr Hall and members on both sides of the Parliament who have made their position public, would find offensive. It is extraordinary that under those circumstances any further question should be raised about the construction site.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to Mr Morris's contribution to the debate on the choice of the final tender, it is the case that Mr Morris prepared on his own behalf, as I understand it, rather than on behalf of any committee, a lengthy submission drawing attention to certain things that he thought needed the further attention of Cabinet before a decision was made. Every matter raised by Mr Morris was dealt with fully by Cabinet and was the subject of very detailed briefing and, in some instances, very thorough questioning by members of Cabinet anxious to assure themselves that the process was complete, satisfactory and beyond reproach in every respect.

The Cabinet did so satisfy itself and made a decision that was thoroughly informed, and about which there should be no question as to its acceptance. Given the very complex process of evaluation and the integrity that was brought to that process of evaluation by the Department of Defence, it is quite extraordinary that people who ought to know better are still trying, for political reasons of their own, to bring the exercise into some sort of question. There is no foundation whatsoever for that and the Government's decision will stand. Not only will it stand, but also it is very much in the interests of the national economy and the national security that it should so stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Special Minister of State confirm media reports of today that Mr Michael Gore has been charged with a number of offences arising from investigations by the Australian Federal Police?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will confine my answer to the information contained in a Press release issued by the Australian Federal Police, which states:

ANSWER.PARA: Queensland property developer, Mr Michael Graham Gore, of Southport, today appeared in the Southport Magistrate Court on charges over the alleged misrepresentations over sales tax returns.

Australian Federal Police officers early this morning questioned Mr Gore at his home. At about 8 a.m. he accompanied them to the local Southport Police station where he was further questioned. He then accompanied the AFP officers at 11 a.m. to the Southport Magistrate's court where he appeared before Magistrate O'Connor.

He was charged with seventeen counts of attempting to defraud the Commonwealth and of allegedly making seventeen false representations to the Commonwealth with a view to obtaining a benefit. The charges are under the Commonwealth Crimes Act.

It is alleged that the offences relate to the importation from Hong Kong of a number of luxury yachts between 1982 and 1984 for sale in Australia. It is alleged that he made an underpayment of sales tax in excess of $300,000 while he was a director and public officer of Stirling Investments Corporation Pty Ltd.

He was released on bail of $50,000 or two sureties of $25,000 each; that he surrender his passport to the Director of Public Prosecutions office in Brisbane; that he not travel overseas without permission; and that he undertake certain restrictions over the disposal of business assets.
The charges and arrest follow a lengthy investigation by the Australian Federal Police.

That investigation, undertaken in Brisbane, has involved working in co-operation with the Director of Public Prosecutions Office in Brisbane, the Australian Taxation Office and the appropriate authorities in Hong Kong. It would not be appropriate to say more in view of the fact that charges remain to be proved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Senator Walsh, in the course of not answering a question that I addressed to Senator Walsh earlier today in Question Time about whether the Government would give an undertaking not to introduce a gold tax in the unlikely event of its being returned to office, alleged that I had advocated a gold tax. I want to make it quite clear that that is not the case; it never has been the case. In a statement that I issued to the media on 15 June 1985, a few days after the Government's White Paper on taxation was published, in addressing a meeting at Esperance, Western Australia, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government should abandon the White Paper proposal to tax gold . . . The Opposition consistently refused to tax gold when in government and during the last election campaign we gave a commitment not to do so if returned to office.

That was the first statement I made in relation to this matter and it was within a few days of the White Paper proposal. I have issued numerous other statements since then until the Government made its own decision some months ago. I do not propose to read from them, but I have made numerous statements to that effect over a considerable period. In those circumstances, Senator Walsh's attempt to fix me with any support for this proposal is quite outrageous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Yesterday in the Senate debate on education Bills Senator Teague made a lengthy claim that I had attempted to misrepresent a letter from the National Catholic Education Commission. He claimed that I had purposely inserted the word `the' before the word `Commonwealth' in the paragraph that states that the NCEC appreciated my understanding of the importance of Commonwealth programs for children in Catholic schools. Two newspapers-the Sydney Morning Herald and the Canberra Times-followed up Senator Teague's claim and published a story to that effect and, indeed, sought comment from the Catholic Education Commission. Senator Teague's claim was wrong; I did not insert the word `the' when I read from the letter. It is the case that Hansard transcribed the word `the'. However, the audiotape--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition Senators-Ha, ha.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague is very much in the wrong here and I expect an apology. On listening to the audiotape-which has been done-he will find that I did not insert the word `the'. Hansard will be making a written apology to me this afternoon. I expect the same from Senator Teague.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement on the same matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard what the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) said. I based my remarks on her clear statements that appear in Hansard at page 3253 for last Friday. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the four-year funding scheme is one of the proudest achievements of our Government. I should emphasise that the National Catholic Education Commission appreciates and commends our commitment to that scheme and it has welcomed and endorsed our policies.
That is directly untrue, and the Chairman of the Commission in an article that appeared in the Canberra Times of today's date is quoted as follows:

Sir Bernard Callinan agreed that the letter had been misquoted and the meaning had been changed. He said the letter had been written to make a `plea' to the Minister not to reduce the existing funding to catholic schools and was not a statement of political support.

Similarly, the Executive Secretary of the Commission, Sister Mary Reardon, based here in Canberra, is quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald of today's date as follows-and I will read directly from the newspaper article:
The Commission's Executive Secretary, Sister Mary Reardon, said it was `regrettable' that Senator Ryan had added the word `the'--

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't-and please apologise, because you are wrong.
—To complete that sentence-

SPEECH.PARA: because `it then becomes possible for people to interpret it-
meaning the letter-
in a way that was not intended by the Commission'.

I do not apologise to the Minister for Education because her clear statement which I quoted at the outset of my remarks here today shows that she wished to construe in that letter that the National Catholic Education Commission was directly supporting the four-year funding program of the Government-and that is not true-and that she wished to construe that the National Catholic Education Commission supports the Government's policies, and that also is not true. Therefore, no apology is due to this Minister. She needs to apologise to the Senate for misleading the Senate and the public of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to have a debate about whose policies are most acceptable to the Catholic Education--
—On a point of order, Mr President: Has Senator Ryan sought leave to speak?
—Order! I am waiting for Senator Ryan to seek leave.
—I seek leave to make a statement.

—Mr President, I will not enter into a full-scale debate. TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to order, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

In doing so, I do not believe there is a need formally to seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard because the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1986 has already been dealt with by the Senate and has now been put back on the Notice Paper. I will take this opportunity, if I may, to add to the second reading speech of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) as previously delivered on this Bill and also to make some points, which need to be made now for the record as a prelude to the media debate, which I hope we will get to later this afternoon, about the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill 1987. I foreshadow that during the Committee stage of debate the Government will move the amendments that have been circulated to honourable senators to both the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill and the Broadcasting Amendment Bill.

With respect to the ownership and control Bill, it is proposed that the 75 per cent population reach rule be reduced to a 60 per cent population reach rule. The Government has agreed to such an amendment to enable this Bill to succeed in its purpose of creating and enhancing the competitive environment in which the commercial television industry can operate and grow. The practical effect of shifting from 75 per cent to 60 per cent is to prevent certain companies currently approaching 60 per cent from having any prescribed interests beyond this level. In doing so, the Government acknowledges concerns in certain quarters that 75 per cent may, in some circumstances, have been more generous than is necessary. The reduced maximum reach should allow more opportunities for some more licensees to develop and participate in programming and production. The substantive purpose of the Bill will remain unaltered.

The second source of contention has been that clause in the Bill which limits persons who own licences, in approved markets, to the old two-station rule if there is a multi-channel services permit in relation to that licence. This was a deliberate preference by the Government to encourage aggregation and thus competition in enlarged regional markets. As the Minister has stated, a fundamental tenet of both the broadcasting Bills has been encouragement and enhancement of competitive influences in the commercial television industry. It has been asserted that this provision discriminates against operators who choose MCS. The Government has reviewed this aspect in the context of the wider objective of the Bill. The amendments moved in the Government's name include provisions which will allow a licensee who elects to go MCS in an approved market to acquire further commercial television interests beyond the two-station rule in markets in which he would provide a service in competition with another service. These markets will be: Firstly, mainland metropolitan markets; secondly, approved markets proceeding directly to aggregation; and, thirdly, the Tasmanian market, once a second independent licence is in place.

A grandfathering clause has been included, which recognises that a person may possibly have already acquired two licences under the present two-station rule in the expectation that they will be within approved markets in which there will be MCS services provided. These persons will be grandfathered in relation to their interests held on 2 June 1987 and will thus be able to provide MCS services in relation to both licences. Any further expansion of interests by these persons will, however, be confined to interests within competitive markets. None of these amendments affect that part of the equalisation Bill which provides that a person may not have a prescribed interest in two or more commercial television licences in the same approved market.

The amendments to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill modify the mechanism for moving to equalisation. After noting various concerns about the mechanism currently provided for in the Bill, we are prepared to modify them in a way which will continue to recognise the Government's primary objective of moving to three competitive commercial television services in regional areas. The Government has always been mindful that the equalisation legislation will entail substantial change to the environment in which the regional television industry has operated.

The Government has had to balance these considerations with its fundamental commitment to give the five million regional viewers who currently have access to only one commercial television service a level of service currently enjoyed by metropolitan Australia. The Senate has so far not seen fit to pass the legislation. A source of some contention has been the so-called one in, all in rule, whereby if one licensee in an approved market chooses to go directly to aggregation, then all licensees in the approved market will proceed directly to aggregation. Notwithstanding the Government's preference for aggregated competitive markets, this decision point has been one the Government has deliberately left to the broadcasting industry.

The Government, in good faith, has now decided to try to find a way around the apparent impasse that has developed by making a modification to the so-called one in, all in rule. The proposed new formulation is that, if two or more licensees in the approved market give notice to the Minister that they wish to proceed immediately towards aggregation in the approved market, that market will proceed immediately towards aggregation. This will have the effect of replacing the one in, all in rule with a two in, all in rule. The proposed amendment will prevent a situation where two licensees who are eligible for consolidation as specified in the indicative plan will be able to give two separate notices to the Minister for aggregation. This new formulation should meet a major concern of some sections of the industry and of some honourable senators opposite. These modifications will ensure that the competitive elements of the Government's policy are retained and will prevent circumstances whereby licensees operating in MCS mode within approved markets are able to entrench themselves further in a monopolistic situation. These amendments do not affect provisions of the legislation ensuring that a company or person may not have a prescribed interest in two or more commercial television licences in the same approved market.

Mr President, as a consequence of these proposed amendments, and of the period now to be devoted to the election, the Government considers it desirable to allow a period of analysis and digestion for interested parties affected by the legislation to review and consider their corporate attitude. We are mindful that these amendments may cause some re-evaluation of intentions. Therefore, the Government proposes to amend the equalisation Bill to provide that it will come into operation 60 days after it receives royal assent. This will have no practical implication for the operation of the Bill but recognises the impact the changes may have on industry. It also recognises the administrative consequences of the electoral process.

The opportunity has also been taken to include a technical amendment to enable a company with a grandfathered interest which constitutes a majority interest-that is, a greater than 51 per cent shareholding interest-in another company to make loans to that company without losing its grandfathered status. These proposed amendments do not significantly alter the purpose or the integrity of the Bills. I also take this opportunity to reiterate the Government's commitment to a remote commercial television service-or RCTS-for the eastern States. The Government is disappointed that the two consortia which currently hold the licences in the south-east and north east service areas have not been able at this stage to fulfil their commitment and sign a service contract with Aussat Pty Ltd. However, let me assure the Senate that it remains the Government's firm intention to ensure that an RCTS service will be available to people in all parts of Australia who live in remote areas.

Finally, Senator Harradine has raised two matters with the Government. The first is the issue of penalties available to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on breach of program or advertising standards. Senator Harradine correctly notes that the only sanctions able to be imposed are either very severe-cancellation or suspension of a licence-or, arguably, rather mild-namely an admonishment. The Government has considered widening the range of penalties but there are constitutional doubts as to whether a power to impose monetary penalties, for example, could be conferred on the ABT. This matter has been discussed with the Minister for Communications and he has authorised me to undertake that the Government will now seek further legal advice in clarification of this issue, which will be provided to Senator Harradine. Following that step and depending on the advice, the Government will reconsider the matter of appropriate penalties.

Secondly, Senator Harradine has drawn attention to the undertaking given by Senator Button, in the debate in this place in 1983 on the passage of the ABC Act. The undertakings related to the complaints process contained in section 82 of the Act. The Minister for Communications informs me that he has recently received advice as to the handling of complaints by the ABC, in particular, complaints which do not fall squarely within section 82. The Government believes that the ABC must have a proper and credible complaint handling procedure. The ABC has been addressing this matter and, as I understand it, a proposal for reform has been recently discussed by the ABC Board. The Government places considerable importance on this matter. It is to be hoped that the ABC brings its consideration of complaints handling reform to an early conclusion. Unless the ABC has public credibility on this issue, it will not be in a good position to resist claims that it should be subject to an external complaints monitor, as applies, for example, to the British Broadcasting Corporation.

Mr President, our overriding and pre-eminent objective in this whole package of legislation has been both to lay the framework for a viable competitive commercial television industry and to facilitate the provision of additional commercial services to the five million Australians presently receiving only one. Accordingly, I commend this Bill and the whole package of legislation to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now about to commence debating the so-called media package comprising the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1986 and five cognate Bills. These Bills are now under a guillotine imposed by the Government and supported by the National Party of Australia.
—And three Independents.

—And three so-called Independents-Senator Georges, Senator Siddons and Senator Vallentine. This guillotine now limits the debate on the second reading to four hours with one hour for the Committee stage. That is disgraceful. It is an indication of what is happening with the whole media package and the nonsense that has gone on in this Parliament in relation to media legislation. These Bills disclose a fundamental difference between the Liberal Party and the Government. The Liberal Party is concerned about people and about providing them, in this case, with decent television services across the nation. The Liberal Party is worried about the small ordinary person out in the sticks or in the suburbs and the sort of television program that person is able to watch.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is concerned with getting the support of the owners of television, radio and newspapers-the media barons-for its election purposes. Some years ago the former Premier of New South Wales, Mr Neville Wran, introduced the greatest public bribe this nation has ever seen. Mr Wran bribed two-thirds of the media in his State of New South Wales with certain Lotto arrangements which still continue. The New South Wales right wing of the Australian Labor Party has now brought that tactic to Canberra. Mr Hawke and Mr Keating have adopted it. This must be the second greatest public bribe in this nation's history.

These are bribes whereby the funds of taxpayers are being used to enable the Labor Party to get publicity support in its electioneering campaign. Have we not seen aspects and examples of that happening across the nation in recent weeks? For example, some journalists have been writing stories that there are differences within the Liberal Party on this package. The differences are not in the Liberal Party. Mr Duffy the other day acknowledged that the Labor Party had spent over 16 hours in debate on this matter, including six hours debate in Cabinet. After six hours of debate in Cabinet he was rolled and Mr Hawke's and Mr Keating's package was passed. It was then said that the Labor Party was not prepared to change its mind. But today we heard Senator Evans acknowledge that the Labor Party is prepared to change its mind. Is there anyone who doubts that many members of the Labor Party are desperately concerned about this sell-out to the media barons? Of course they are. There is dissent right around the Labor Party, not only within this Parliament but outside around the nation, about this sell-out to media barons to maintain public support in the media, on radio, television and newspapers, that the Labor Party is so desperately seeking.

We see that the Government is continuing with its so-called `animals'-its NMLS or National Media Liaison Service media campaign. It has 17 journalists working for Ministers, all involved in trying to sell the Australian Labor Party to the people of Australia in the forthcoming election. This package is simply a bribe to the media barons of this country. It is designed to ensure that they will control national networks right across Australia. Just imagine that! The Labor Party has introduced this package of legislation to ensure that three or four, maybe five, media barons will be able to control the whole of the national networks of television right across Australia. The Government would have us believe that the Liberal Party would deny regional viewers the right to more and better services. That is about as believable as Mr Hawke's statements that there would be no early election.

TALK.START.PARA: —And no capital gains tax.
—And no capital gains tax. This Government is exposed by its Commissioner for the Future, Mr Phillip Adams, who, in his article in the Bulletin of 2 June 1987, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the next couple of years we will see the slow death of State and regional television as the new owners shed staff through dismissals or attrition and, slowly but surely, close down local production. Australian television will increasingly be Sydney television, reticulated by satellite, cable or what-have-you.

(Take the situation in Victoria, where Premier John Cain will find it hard to get his head on the screen. Apart from the Victorian version of The 7.30 Report, there's not a local public affairs program left. So people throughout Australia will see endless images of NSW leader Barrie Unsworth, but Burke, Bannon and Gray will be so far off-Broadway as to be invisible. Well, they're not going to like it. And, in the passage of time, local viewers won't like it either.)

I thoroughly agree with Mr Adams. I say this to honourable members and senators who travel around the regional areas of Australia campaigning or putting their points of view: Up to this stage, when they have visited a country town they have frequently had the opportunity to appear on that country town's television station. That will not happen within 12 months or so after networking goes right around Australia, because that local country television station will not be providing that sort of local news service. That is absolutely the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is completely wrong, Austin.

—I hear Senator Boswell saying that that is wrong. I guarantee Senator Boswell that, within 12 to 18 months, if he visits Rockhampton he will not get a guernsey on Rockhampton television. If he visits Mount Isa he will not get a guernsey on Mount Isa television. Of course, he may not even be a senator by then so he may not be visiting those areas as one. But, whoever the senators for Queensland are, when they visit the regional areas of Queensland-Maryborough, Darling Downs, Cairns or Mackay-they will all find that what is being shown in those areas is some form of networked program from New South Wales, from Sydney, with perhaps some very small regional service, perhaps some local weather details. Honourable senators will have seen the sorts of weather reports that are provided in the United States of America, where the whole of the nation is covered in about 15 seconds. One is told that it is warm in the north and cold in the south, or vice versa, or whatever the case happens to be. That is about the detail of the weather report one gets in the United States, whereas, as honourable senators know, nowadays we get a decent weather report from our regional television services. We also get a decent regional coverage of what is happening and the news of the day in the area for which a regional service provides coverage. But we will not be getting that once we have networking.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke keeps saying-and apparently now Senator Boswell goes along with it-that that will not happen. It is my belief that it will certainly happen. It is also the belief of the people of Melbourne, who have now seen what has happened to Channel 7 in Melbourne. What have the people of Melbourne done with regard to Channel 7 now that it is being networked from Sydney? They have opted out of watching Channel 7 in very large numbers. Channel 7 in Melbourne is now in great trouble because it is simply showing a program networked from Sydney, and the people of Melbourne do not like watching such a program. But, of course, the channel has no alternative to showing networked programs because of the costs which are now involved-thanks, I might say, to this Government's so-called media package.

This Government, continuing as usual on its merry way of legislating by way of Press release, issued a Press release on I think 27 November. What happened?
