TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as the third National Party speaker on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1986, the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1987, the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill 1987, and the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. It is interesting to follow Senator Harradine. I can understand how he believes that broadcasting standards are the real issue we should be discussing. I see only a very tenuous connection between this package of Bills and broadcasting standards, which I think come under other headings. Nevertheless, I want to answer some of the criticisms that have been levelled against the National Party for changing its stance on these Bills. I object to the charges of bribery and corruption that were laid against us in the Senate tonight. Even the three senators who have spoken on the Bills took different attitudes at different times during the development of the legislation. It was not really until the Government came to the negotiating table and decided the three amendments that we are debating tonight that the National Party came to an agreement on the passage of the package, even considering the cross-media ownership provisions with which we do not agree but which are part of the package. It is more important that we see an improvement of services to the rural areas than that we worry about the cross-media ownership provisions at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refute the charges that were made by three of the speakers about bribery and corruption within the Party in relation to the Bills. Certainly, no pressure has been put on me one way or the other. I have been lobbied from all sides on the Bills, but I believe that consideration has been completely impartial from all sections of the National Party. Our concern is for the provision of better service for the rural areas. I suppose that it could be said that the Opposition and the Government have had eight to ten years to formulate proposals that provide better services for the regional areas and, undoubtedly, there are different methods for doing it. Following all the consultation that has taken place over the last couple of years-for example, between the Department of Communications, the regional services, the networks and the remote area television services, the satellite administration people, as well as the Government itself-aggregation and equalisation was the method chosen to provide services to eastern Australia. This is all that it applies to; it does not affect services, say, in the Northern Territory, Western Australia or South Australia. It gives increased and better services to rural areas in eastern Australia, and one cannot argue with that.

As time is limited I shall refer to only a few areas of concern. One of those concerns localism and the provision of appropriate local services. I have studied all the issues, and I think that with the competition that will exist between the three commercial stations and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation a denigration of localism will not occur. After all, it has been shown quite clearly that if localism is neglected, whichever station neglects it will lose its audience reach. So I do not see that as being a major problem. Poison pills were referred to. The one in all in rule has been amended by the Government so that there will be a majority decision. Further, the ability of a television proprietor to expand in markets has been taken care of by another amendment. For example, if a smaller television station is being forced to aggregate into a market because two larger stations request it, that smaller station will not be precluded from developing as it will be allowed to expand into other aggregated markets in order to increase its audience reach.

In relation to the audience reach provisions, the 60 per cent limit that has been agreed to I think is really the result of a series of horse trading arrangements. It went from 34 per cent to 75 per cent, and some people even wanted 100 per cent, but it looks as though there will not need to be any major dislocations in relation to all those people who have made purchases since the Minister's announcement of what the Government proposed in this legislation.

One thing that concerns me about the implementation of these Bills is the enormous expansion of the bureaucracy that will be required in order to administer the provisions. The bureaucracy always likes to see itself expand. With the provision of aggregation, equalisation and all the administration that will be required with the inspections, accreditations, and even the affiliations, an enormous expansion of bureaucracy will occur. I presume that that will be funded by licensing fees from regional stations, and let us hope that it will be revenue negative. However, I find it hard to imagine that such an enormous expense will be revenue negative.

The result that we have come up with is only one of the means by which better services can be provided in rural areas. I think the method proposed is the best one that we could come up with at the moment. It is no good letting the industry go on and on in a vacuum with no rules by which to operate. Certainly, the old system was outdated and incapable of providing the expanded services required. Future developments could not be left to occur in a haphazard way. In the very near future an expansion of technology will occur, which I think will render effete much of what we are doing now. I think that a lot of the specialised services-I refer to fibre optics, cable television and the video and audio entertainment and information services scheme-will wind up being bypassed by satellite transmissions, which will bring us into contact with the whole of the rest of the world without the need to have the services that we are proposing now. Nevertheless, there will always be some need for land-based transmission of television services, and at least when these measures are in place the infrastructure will all be there and capable of expanding in whichever way communications services develop in the very near future.

I note that we have reached the time for the conclusion of the debate on this package of Bills. At this stage I indicate that the National Party, far from changing its position, has had a changing position throughout the development of the legislation, and we now thank the Government for accommodating us with the amendments that it has made. They have effectively removed the poison pills from the legislation and the National Party is now in the position of being able to support the legislation.

Without going into great detail about the meaning of the amendments, previously it had been proposed that in regional areas if one licensee within a market area decided to become aggregated, all of the other licensees within that market area had to do likewise. On behalf of the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, I will say a number of things about localism, a word which has been much used in this debate. Insofar as programming is concerned, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, previously the Broadcasting Control Board, has sought to foster to the maximum extent possible the broadcasting of programs by licensees, especially regional licensees, which are relevant and valuable to their communities, such as local news and weather and some local sport and current affairs. These matters are important.

The Broadcasting Act contains a fundamental requirement that licensees provide `adequate and comprehensive' programming. That obligation can be rendered only in the context of the local needs of communities in the service area associated with a particular licensee. TALK.START.PARA: —We have a very limited time for discussion of these important amendments, and I shall be brief. I respond first to the statements by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) which have been read out by Senator Walsh. Frankly, I think that they are a snide attack on regional television stations. The Minister spoke of their presenting only 6 per cent of locally produced programs. The truth is that regional television stations are extremely popular around the nation, particularly when they emphasise local aspects. Local news services rate higher than the Cosby Show and that is the highest rating program in Australia. To suggest that regional television stations are in some way or other not pulling their weight is a snide and unfair attack upon them. I am sure that they will be most disappointed when they read the Minister's comments.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the amendments which have been moved by the Government. Frankly, the amendments are cosmetic in relation to compulsory aggregation for two reasons. Firstly, they still continue the concept of an approved market. That means that regional television licensees are not able to choose the areas into which they wish to move or with which they wish to aggregate. The Government has defined the approved market and left regional television stations with that approved market as defined by the Government. For example, Albury is required to move in with Ballarat and Bendigo in Victoria and is unable to move north into arrangements with New South Wales, if that is its wish. Therefore, to suggest that this change assists in some way or other is a nonsense. In fact, it is still compulsory aggregation.

Secondly, one must look at the practical effect of changing the one in all in rule to the two in all in rule. I do not know whether all honourable senators understand this concept, but there are three regional television stations. Up to now the Government had proposed, grossly unfairly, that if one of those stations wanted to aggregate into the approved market, all three would be required to aggregate into that market. Under this amendment, which as I understand it has been instituted as a result of a request of the National Party, if two of those stations want to aggregate then the third will be required to do so. In other words, it will be two in all in instead of one in all in.

What will be the practical effect? Let us visualise the position. There are three regional stations in an area. To take the three I mentioned before-Albury Ballarat and Bendigo-they will be watching each other like hawks. As soon as one of them, say Albury, wants to aggregate-and we know that it wants to do so because it has said so-and it enters into a deal with, say, Channel 9 in Melbourne, when aggregation occurs it will be networked to that channel. Ballarat and Bendigo will look at each other and immediately jump to aggregate with one of the stations in Melbourne. They may choose Channel 10 because they will not want to be associated with Channel 7 which has lost such support. To think that any one of the three could wait for some years before they entered into networking is a nonsense from the point of view of sensible businessmen. The result will be that as soon as this legislation is passed, those regional television stations around Australia will be almost obligated to jump into some networking arrangement with one of the metropolitan stations, otherwise someone else will beat them to the punch. They will be falling over one another to enter into networking arrangements. That is exactly our criticism of this legislation, that it is designed to ensure that networking will occur right around Australia to the benefit of the media barons in the capital cities and to the detriment of the regional networks.

I wish to refer briefly to this one-line amendment, which is the most important amendment to this Bill. As originally presented, the Bill allowed owners to acquire television stations or transmitters with a reach of up to 75 per cent of the national audience. As Senator Boswell observed earlier in the debate, this does not mean that that owner has 75 per cent of the market; it means that he has a potential for 75 per cent of the market. The amendment cuts that figure back to 60 per cent. That figure is repeated many times throughout the Bill. The other major amendment concerns regional telecasting. As the Bill was originally presented, those regional--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. Could I have clarification of whether we are dealing with all the broadcasting Bills together?

—We are dealing with the Broadcasting (Ownership and Control) Bill and Senator Walsh has, by leave, moved 10 Government amendments. I note that you, Senator Siddons, have an amendment which you may move later if you wish to do so.

—I do not intend to speak for long; so Senator Siddons will have plenty of time to move his amendment. I turn to the second major amendment that I have moved. In the original Bill those operators within a market area who opted for the multichannel services were tied to the two-station rule, unless they already had only one station in which case they were tied to a de facto one-station rule. They could not buy interests in any other television licence throughout the country while they had opted for multichannel services. The amendment means that such operators may buy in other competitive market areas up to the overall limit of 60 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other amendment is fairly technical and concerns cases where a parent company has a 50 per cent or greater than 50 per cent interest in a subsidiary which is a licensee. As originally drafted, the Bill required that that parent company could not make loans to the licensee without risking forfeiture of the licence. In its original form the Bill provided that if such a holding or parent company made additional loans to its subsidiary which held a television licence it would lose the protection of the so-called grandfather clause in the legislation. The amendment ensures that such a parent company may lend money to its subsidiary licensee company, but it may not increase its shareholding in such a company.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chair-man, although we have agreed to the Government moving all 10 amendments together, could we deal with amendment No. 2, which relates to replacing 75 per cent with 60 per cent, and then amendment No. 10, which does the same thing? The Liberal Party would like to deal with those amendments separately because we will oppose them but not the other eight amendments. I believe that Senator Siddons and Senator Vigor have amendments which also relate to that matter. The Opposition cannot see any sense in reducing the percentage from 75 to 60 or in making any other arrangement. There is no merit in doing so. The Government and the National Party of Australia have taken over this legislation and intend to get it through the Senate. We think it is wrong and we will oppose these two amendments. The other amendments are not unreasonable and we will not oppose them.

—Is it the wish of the Committee that Government amendments Nos 2 and 10 be considered separately? There being no objection, it is so ordered. The question before the Chair is that amendments Nos 1 and 3 to 9 inclusive be agreed to.
—The question now is that Government amendments Nos 2 and 10 be agreed to.

—These amendments allow for a 60 per cent audience reach rather than the originally proposed 75 per cent. I wish to reiterate my previous comments. I think that it is appalling that the Government, with the support of the National Party of Australia, should move such amendments. We already have the greatest concentration of media ownership in the Western world. I and others will oppose these amendments. I feel very sad this evening that I have not been able to convince important members of the Senate that something less than 50 per cent ownership is the least that the Australian people should expect. I will move an amendment in due course to the effect that 43 per cent ownership is a reasonable compromise. If the 60 per cent audience reach amendment is passed the whole ownership of the media will be open to takeovers and unbelievable concentration and we can look to a danger of our democracy being subverted by the owners of the media, who are all-powerful. I can only reiterate that at least to reduce the level of audience reach down to 43 per cent, or some percentage lower than 50 per cent, is the least of the safeguards that we should expect in this day and age of takeovers. We have already seen how many powerful forces in this community are anxious to get control of media outlets.

—I also speak in opposition to the amendments and in general to the whole principle of increasing monopolisation of the Australian media. It is very dangerous in a democracy to allow large companies to have control of more and more media outlets. That is exactly the reverse of what should be happening. Information in a democracy is a very important tool. The increasing monopolisation, whether 75 per cent or 60 per cent that we now seem to be facing, is detrimental to a democracy. The right to information is fundamental. I believe that diverse sources of information are required, not further monopolisation. As a representative of what some people like to refer to as a minority group-the peace movement, which is increasing in its numbers and soon to be a majority group; however at this stage it is a minority group-it is very difficult to put points across in the media as it is now. Increasing monopolisation in any shape or form will further disadvantage people who hold views which are not generally accepted by the establishment. That is indeed a retrograde step for the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will oppose these amendments. We have an amendment to this clause which suggests a very sensible figure of 22 per cent, instead of the 60 per cent which the Government is proposing. There is a rationale for these figures. It is probably useful, before honourable senators face the vote on the 60 per cent amendments, to just point out some of the rationale. My foreshadowed amendment for 22 per cent is based on granting somebody a licence in one of the major cities of Sydney or Melbourne. That figure corresponds to just above the size of the Sydney market. This means that people cannot control both the large central market and all the regional markets. They cannot control more than the two major cities. They cannot get full control of more than three of the provincial capitals, Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth and Hobart-the BAPH States. SPEECH.PARA: We believe that if we introduce the 22 per cent figure-and under the legislation there is the ability for people to divest themselves of this power-we will be moving in the right direction. —I am prepared to say subjective or even arbitrary. I believe, however, that anybody who tries to put forward a figure as low as 22 per cent is going too far down. What is more important, at least within a pretty substantial range of market reach, is whether there is competition within a market. The thrust of the whole package of Bills which have been moved by the Government is that there will be competition, if not immediately, in the near future, with competition being defined as access to three commercial television licensees as well as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

—Could we not? It seems to me that somebody somewhere up high, in Rambo style, has made a decision which has now been imposed upon the lot of us, in spite of--

It is no use Senator Collard shaking his head, because he is likely to be the victim.
—So be it, then.
—So be it.
—Come on, George. You are not lifting the standard of debate as you suggested you were going to. You are wasting our time.

—I am sorry, but I thought that Senator Lewis was wasting the time of the chamber by not representing the policy of his Party. As far as I can gather, the policy of Senator Lewis's Party is, on the one hand, 43 per cent, as expounded by Mr Macphee; or on the other hand the open market-place proposition of Mr Beale which says: `We will all go out to the market-place to let everyone have what they want, providing, of course, that we get a price for it'. TALK.START.PARA: —I raise for the sake of the Senate a matter that Mr Tim Fischer, the honourable member for Farrer, raised in the House of Representatives on 29 May 1987, and I refer to House of Representatives Hansard pages 3654 and 3655, in relation to the actions of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) regarding the ceremony that was held at the Australian War Memorial on 22 May 1986 for the proclamation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I do this with some concern, but firstly I point out that, as a result of what this Government has done to the Freedom of Information Act, in order to get the material which Mr Fischer was able ultimately to extract from the Department he had to pay $225.20 to get this information out of the bureaucracy. The Australian Labor Party lectured us for seven years about freedom of information. The Liberal-National Party coalition Government introduced the freedom of information legislation. Notwithstanding our having introduced it, we were regularly hammered by people such as Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Grimes and Senator Walsh about freedom of information. Yet the Australian Labor Party gets into office and puts fees on so-called freedom of information such that a member of the House has to pay $225.20 to get this information out of the Department.
—I had to pay $400 to get CEP information.

—Senator Michael Baume had to pay $400-odd. I was placed in the same position in relation to matters to do with my portfolio responsibility and was not able to pay $756 in order to get information to which I believe I was justly entitled, and there can be no doubt that Mr--
—Why didn't you put it on the Notice Paper?

—What is the good of putting it on the Notice Paper? I point out to Senator Georges that questions never get answered. Questions are answered in absolute gobbledegook instead of providing the information which properly ought to be provided. I really think the Government ought to refund this money to Mr Fischer, considering what he has been able to disclose. That is the first point that I want to make.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the second point. I very much regret the fact that my old friend in this chamber, Senator Gietzelt, has clearly misled the Senate. Senator Gietzelt and I have been opponents in this Parliament ever since I arrived here 11 years ago. He and I have clashed frequently in the chamber and at committee meetings and all the rest of it. However, all in all somehow or other I have some respect for him, and I know that he is a sincere fellow. But in this case I have to say that somehow or other the Minister did not understand what was going on in his office. That is clear from the material which Mr Fischer laid before the House of Representatives on 29 May. As a result of the information that he was able to obtain under the freedom of information provisions, Mr Fischer was able to indicate that at folio 19 there was a note to the Deputy Secretary of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, Mr John Bright, which said in part:

On Friday, 2 May, I telephoned the Australian War Memorial to discuss the possibility of using some part of it for the ceremony on 22 May. When I arrived, the Director, Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, asked to see me about the background to the ceremony and to offer his views.

He pointed out that, to date, the memorial had only ever been used for purposes directly related to its activities and he was concerned that the Australian War Memorial could be criticised for being the venue of a political statement. He asked that it be made quite clear that it was the choice of the Minister and the VEA announcement was to highlight benefits to veterans and their dependants. He asked me to pass his thoughts to the Minister, which I did through a meeting with Cynthia Martin later in the day.

Cynthia Martin works in the Minister's office, and it is quite clear that if Mr Bright mentioned it to Cynthia Martin, then Cynthia Martin would have mentioned it to the Minister. It may be that the Minister was so busy that he was unable to recall the matter, but there is no doubt that at least his office was advised of it. I do not want to accuse Miss Martin of not having passed on the message to the Minister, but either that happened or the Minister was so advised. In other words, it is quite clear that on Friday, 2 May the then Director of the Australian War Memorial Jim Flemming-since sacked as a result of all this, I might say-had informed the Public Relations and Publicity Officer, Mr John Bright, that he objected to the use of the Memorial for the reasons that I just set out. Mr Fischer went on to say that in a formal letter dated 9 May Mr John Bright wrote to the Director in the following terms:
The Minister has now confirmed that he wishes to proceed with the ceremony at that location on Thursday, 22 May at 2.30 p.m.
It is very clear that the direction had come from the Minister. From examination of the file, Mr Fischer was able to ascertain that there was a subsequent note at folio 37, which stated:
Cynthia Martin confirmed this morning that the Minister has agreed to the arrangements set out in my minute of 6 May.
There was also a crucial minute, dated 22 April-that was before all the matters that I have talked about were raised-which noted:
The Minister has requested a major launch of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill to coincide with the proclamation on 8 May. He would like a ceremony arranged at the War Memorial.

It is clear that the Minister's staff were saying to the Public Relations and Publicity Officer, Mr Bright, that the Minister wanted that function held at the War Memorial. It is clear that that information was passed on to Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, who then said that he had some objections to it. Those objections went back to the Minister's office and back came the request from the Minister's office that the Minister had confirmed that that was what he wanted. Yet, all the way along the Minister keeps saying-and let me quote what the Minister told the Senate on 14 November 1986:

Never at any time did I direct the Australian War Memorial to perform a function or to make its premises available for the function. It was a decision of the Department to hold the function. It was the decision of the Department that it should be held at the Australian War Memorial. It was then the responsibility of the Department . . . Never at any stage was it a ministerial direction.
Further, on 18 November 1986 the Minister said:
I know of no occasion when any recommendation was made to me that the ceremony could not be held at the Australian War Memorial.

I raise this matter because, clearly, the Minister must respond to these allegations and explain to the Senate whether he acknowledges that in fact the directions were coming from his office. If he wishes to say that he did not know about the directions from his office, the Senate may be able to understand that, but at this stage it is clear from the material discovered by Mr Fischer that the directions were coming from the Minister's office and in the Minister's name. His staff was saying: `This is what the Minister wants'. So, as Mr Fischer says, these statements of the Minister to the Senate sit very unhappily with the material disclosed under the freedom of information provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to make some urgent and necessary comments on the report of the Commissioner of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Chamberlain Convictions, the Hon. Mr Justice Morling, as a result of some publicity which has occurred since the release of that document this morning. The matter to which I particularly want to refer is the indication that in some way Mr Justice Morling's report has been less than a clearing of the Chamberlain name because Mr Justice Morling has not in fact quashed the convictions against the Chamberlains. Much arises from that point, including the question of what compensation might reasonably be paid to the Chamberlains for their enormous ordeal and the horrendous financial costs they have incurred as a result of the events of the last few years. To put that in proportion one ought to look at Mr Morling's report. On page 8 he states clearly what he saw his role as being:

SPEECH.PARA: In effect, what I am required to do is to consider the whole of the evidence led before me and, without placing an onus of proof on any party, to decide whether there is a doubt as to the Chamberlains' guilt.

Mr Justice Morling very properly at no stage sees any duty on him to quash the conviction against the Chamberlains. That would not be his proper place. That should be done by the Government of the Northern Territory which has, as a result of Mr Justice Morling's report, now a duty and obligation to do so as soon as possible.

I turn briefly to the report and the points and conclusions which the Commissioner has made. I have seldom read a document which is a more damning indictment of court proceedings or proceedings in any place against anybody. There is no doubt whatsoever that again and again, like the tolling of a bell, this report-an admirably written, clear report from Mr Justice Morling-demolishes the Crown case in every possible respect and reveals it for the fantastic fantasy it always was. On page 160 of the report, for instance, Mr Justice Morling, after a long, most careful and learned study of all the questions concerning blood in cars and things of that type, comes to this conclusion:

If there was any blood present in the car, it was present in only small quantities in the area of the hinge on the passenger seat and beneath. I conclude that none of Mrs Kuhl's tests established that any such blood was Azaria's . . . Thus, if the results-
that is, of the tests-

are relied upon, they suggest that any blood in the hinge area was shed after 17 August 1980. Whether this be correct or not, the presence of a small quantity of blood in this area would not justify the drawing of any inference adverse to the Chamberlains.
On page 235 of the report the Commissioner says:

The evidence concerning the soil and plant fragments on the clothing is consistent with the clothed body of the baby being dragged through sand on the dunes east of the camping area and through low vegetation of kinds which grew in that dune country and on the plains between the camping area and the Rock.
On the other hand, if the clothing had been merely taken from the car, buried, disinterred and later placed at the Rock by the Chamberlains-
that is, the Crown's allegation-
one can imagine that it may have picked up some plant material but it is difficult to conceive how it could have collected the quantity and variety of plant material found upon it.
On page 315 the Commissioner refers to the `erroneous assumption made by Professor Chaikin that dingoes cannot cut fabric with their teeth and produce tufts'. The Commissioner states:

This assumption was not based upon any research work, or any scientific writing. He gave it as the strongest reason for his belief that the jumpsuit severances had been made by human hand and not by a dingo. Professor Chaikin's evidence on this point was of great importance . . .

I recall that these are the two points which were raised years ago in this place by a private member's Bill for a commission of inquiry into the Chamberlain case. As I said to the Senate at the time those two points demolished the Crown's case clearly in the mind of any reasonable person. I am glad now that after the enormous effort put in by the Chamberlain innocence committee and many other citizens in this country an inquiry was actually held and that it has come forward and justified those points.

On page 319 Mr Justice Morling makes some very good points about the difficulties and inadequacies of so-called forensic science in Australian court proceedings. He says something that I agree with, which is that the National Forensic Science Institute should be established so that the hit and miss methods that have damned this area of so-called evidence in the past can be got rid of and reasonable standards can be adopted. Mr Justice Morling makes the point:
Furthermore, the existence of such an Institute would hopefully reduce the need to retain experts from overseas.
At page 320 Mr Justice Morling says something else that honourable senators ought to mark, and mark carefully:

The Commission is the second inquiry in recent years arising out of doubts as to scientific evidence. The other was the Splatt inquiry conducted into the conviction of Edward Charles Splatt for murder in South Australia. The report of the Royal Commission, Mr Carl Shannon, Q.C. . . . was made in 1984, some two years after the Chamberlain trial. As a result of his report some changes were made to forensic science procedures in South Australia. The fact that two such inquiries have now been held points up the desirability of further consideration of the proposal to set up a national institute.
We would be doing less than our duty if we did not encourage that point. At page 330 Mr Justice Morling states clearly:

I must now answer the question whether, in the light of all the evidence, there are doubts as to the Chamberlain's guilt. In my opinion, this question must be answered in the affirmative. I do not think any jury could properly convict them on the evidence as it now appears.
He states further:

I am conscious of the fact that the Chamberlain's, convictions were upheld in the High Court. On the evidence as it appeared at the trial, two of the five members of the Court thought that the convictions were unsafe. I am confident that the appeal would have succeeded if the evidence had been as it now appears.

That would have been very difficult in view of the fact that the High Court is an appellate court. Mr Justice Morling's final words in the report are of considerable drama and bear directly on what I am saying. He says:

In my opinion, if the evidence before the Commission had been given at the trial, the trial judge would have been obliged to direct the jury to acquit the Chamberlains on the ground that the evidence could not justify their conviction.

He can hardly, I would think, go further than that. In the light of those comments, it would be absolutely intolerable for the Northern Territory Government to continue to make statements about pardons and nonsense of that sort. A pardon is not required under the circumstances-it would be a gross injustice. What is required is legislation to be brought in, as soon as possible, by the Northern Territory Government to acquit the Chamberlains, and it should be done with apologies to them, not the sort of comments we heard through the media today from Mr Paul Everingham, who said that he was sorry the Chamberlains ever went to the Northern Territory and that they had cost the Territory $10m. What sort of statement is that to come from a person who claims to have any aspirations in public life?

The damage is done to the Chamberlains and it has been done by the same Northern Territory Government of which Mr Paul Everingham was Chief Minister at the time this matter began. I suggest that the lesson of history will be that that same Mr Paul Everingham will have a lot to answer for when all is said and done. I will allow history to be his judge, but be sure it will be his judge-there is no doubt about that. If the Northern Territory does not act promptly, the Australian Democrats will seek action from this Parliament under the undoubted residual powers it has in the Constitution over the Northern Territory, the same powers that justified the drafting of my Bill for a commission of inquiry into the Chamberlain case, to bring forward legislation in this Parliament to quash the Chamberlains' convictions.

I shall not be in the Senate myself after Thursday, but my successor, Mr Paul McLean, has undertaken that he will make this one of his first duties if he is elected. If he is not elected, I trust that other honourable senators will have the sense of justice to do that. This is a principle of enormous importance. It was a principle of importance that the innocence committee was espousing when it fought to have a fresh commission hearing. It would have been of tremendous significance-a precedent in the Australian community-if a person who had fresh evidence to be heard were not given that opportunity. Now, as we find, this fresh evidence has convinced the Commission. The same principle applies to the question of whether or not the Chamberlains are now acquitted. We cannot have two courts, one saying they should have been acquitted and the other saying they should not. One or other of those views must prevail. If it does not, and if action is not taken to acquit the Chamberlains, no Australian in future can ever feel safe. We will have established a precedent in this country whereby any member of the public-any man or women-could be brought to trial, convicted and gaoled on false, improper or slovenly prepared evidence, as was the case in this matter, and told at the end of their ordeal: `There is nothing in this for you; there are legal technicalities so that you cannot have this compensation'. I know the law exists. I cannot put myself above it or beyond it, and I have no wish to do so. The situation that, if there is a pardon, the Chamberlains are not legally entitled to a cent of compensation, must not be allowed to stand. It is necessary that from some place or another the conviction be quashed by legislation. If that is not done in the Northern Territory Parliament it ought to be done here.

Finally, many issues remain to be resolved following this inquiry. These include the way in which the Northern Territory police carried out the investigation. It would be absolutely appalling if that matter were to be overlooked. It is essential to the conduct of police proceedings that the public have the utmost confidence in the police. This case-whether it be right or wrong, only an investigation can show-aroused deep doubt in the minds of hundreds of thousands of people as to the conduct of the police. It is proper and reasonable that the police concerned in that investigation should now face up to an inquiry of that kind.

The other thing that needs looking at is the role now to be played by forensic evidence in any legal proceedings between this time and the establishment of proper standards which we hope might evolve over a period from the institute which I mentioned earlier. It will not happen quickly. The Chamberlains have been exonerated. I am pleased about that in every possible respect, but perhaps of even more importance for the future is that our legal system and our forensic scientists must now stand their trial.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 12 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What restrictive work practices are in force at Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Limited, which, in the opinion of management, reduce productivity without any compensatory safety or industrial health benefits.

(2) What restrictive work practices in force at Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Limited, while having some safety or industrial health benefits, are done in such a way that comparable benefits could be achieved with less loss of productivity.
(3) What new restrictive work practices, of the type noted above, have come into force in the last year.
(4) What new restrictive work practices, of the type noted above, have been eliminated in the past year and what have been the benefits to productivity in each case.
(5) Has the management advised the Minister for Territories of the total annual cost of these restrictive work practices; if so, what is the total annual cost of these restrictive work practices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Both employer and employee organisations acknowledge that restrictive work practices include a wide range of work and management practices which, when combined, impact upon the efficiency with which labour and/or capital is used by an organisation. In this respect, the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island (PMCI) is no exception. In the context of the extensive restructuring of PMCI over the past few years, however, it is virtually impossible to address and quantify changes in specific work and management practices.
(2) See 1 and 4.
(3) I am not aware of any specific new restrictive work practices which have come into force in the last year.

(4) Recognising that the PMCI work force (including the Executive and Management) has been reduced from around 1300 in 1984 to less than 300, the Government and the PMCI have been continually negotiating with the Union of Christmas Island Workers about complementary changes in work and management practices to ensure productivity has been maintained and improved. The majority of these changes have been documented and now form part of an Industrial Agreement which the parties entered into recently. The Agreement was developed to achieve industrial stability in the mining operation for the next three years. The changes to work and management practices have been so extensive that it is not possible to relate individual work practice changes to specific productivity improvements.
(5) I have not been advised of the annual cost of the restrictive work practices as, in the circumstances outlined above, it is not possible to specifically quantify their cost.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 March 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: In relation to the power in section 21 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission Act 1986, and a similar power contained in section 15 of the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 relating to the summonsing of witnesses to appear before the Commission, can the Attorney-General please supply the following information for the years 1983-84, 1984-85, 1985-86 and 1986-87 (est) for each State-
(1) What was the amount spent on travel for witnesses to Commission hearings each year.
(2) Of this total, how much was spent on airfares.
(3) How many witnesses were called before the Commission, and of these, how many required inter and intrastate air travel.
(4) What was the total amount spent on accommodation and associated travel expenses for witnesses.
(5) What is the minimum notice, in practice, given to an interstate witness when required to appear before the Commission.
(6) Is the power to summons witnesses delegated to other officers of the Commission, apart from a member of the Commission as stated in the Act.
(7) In practice, what is the sum given to a witness for attendance at Commission hearings.
(8) What amount was spent by the Commission for the purpose of reimbursing witnesses for the attendance at Commission hearings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The files of the former Human Rights Commission on which the information would appear are not, at present, readily accessible. Some are in boxes held by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and others are in archives. Departmental financial records do not identify travellers as witnesses.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has, nevertheless, conducted such examination as has been possible of relevant files and has advised that, as best it can ascertain, five witnesses were required to appear before the former Commission. This advice is consistent with the recollections of former senior officers of the Commission. The files also indicate that other witnesses appeared before the Commission but it is not apparent whether they were served with Notices to Appear.
(5) The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has yet to determine a policy on this issue but a tentative view is at least 2 weeks where possible.
(7) A policy on this is yet to be determined by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission but would be commensurate with the Federal Court scale of witnesses expenses.

(8) For the reasons mentioned above, a definite answer is not presently obtainable but inquiries made of former senior officers of the Human Rights Commission indicate that no payments were made to witnesses summonsed before an inquiry.
